image.altText: A man holds open an empty wallet.

items.synopsis: Younger Australians are being forced to change their behaviour to deal with the rising cost of living, a report based on the financial data of 7 million people shows.

title.children: Under 35s cutting back while older Australians continuing to splash out, CBA report shows

image.altText: Joe Biden smiles while sitting infront of a US flag in a conference room.

items.synopsis: The White House says US President Joe Biden may be forced to ditch his planned trip to Australia because of stalled domestic debt ceiling negotiations.

title.children: Joe Biden may have to cancel Australian visit

image.altText: Three firefighters stand outside in the dark in Wellington with one being sprayed with sprinklers

items.synopsis: A devastating fire ravaged through a hostel in New Zealand's capital early Tuesday morning, taking the lives of at least six people. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: What we know about the Loafers Lodge hostel fire

image.altText: Special needs young people in wheelchairs.

items.synopsis: New data reveals that, while remote regions have attracted the highest average plan value, participants in those postcodes spend less due to restricted service provision.

title.children: NDIS participants missing out on services due to provider shortage

image.altText: A bald shirtless man faces a white wall, his back is covered in elaborate tattoos

items.synopsis: Haru felt he had little choice in life but to follow his father's footsteps and become a Japanese gangster. It was a path that landed him in jail for years, but now, he is ready to fight Russian invaders on the front line in Ukraine.

title.children: Why a former Japanese gangster left behind a life of crime to fight for Ukraine

image.altText: A man with short salt and pepper coloured hair and slight beard stands in front of a stone wall

items.synopsis: While New Zealanders have welcomed easier, cheaper pathways to gain Australian citizenship, some say they were left in the dark about plans to abolish an expensive visa that will soon be redundant.

title.children: Rob paid $4,000 for a visa that will soon be 'redundant' — and he's not the only one

image.altText: a husband and wife stand arm-in-arm with bleak expressions in front of an unfinished home

items.synopsis: Mali wanted to achieve the "great Australian dream" of owning her own home. It turned into a nightmare when one of the country's largest builders collapsed.

title.children: 'Unbelievably hard': Families left in limbo after collapse of Porter Davis

image.altText: Bone disc on an X-ray of someone's hands

items.synopsis: During the Cold War, the Soviet government banned jazz, rock 'n' roll and other music. A group of bootleggers came up with an unusual way to distribute the music they loved.

title.children: How X-rays were used to distribute forbidden music across Soviet Russia during the Cold War

image.altText: Heather smiling in her home

items.synopsis: A housing program is cutting people's energy bills and keeping people warmer in Victoria's winter months as many struggle with health issues due to poorly insulated homes.

title.children: Heather used to wear her winter coat and beanie to bed. Not anymore

image.altText: A white man with short hair speaks into a small desk microphone, while wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: ChatGPT boss calls for AI regulation, and rapper Slowthai denies rape charges. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The head of the artificial intelligence company that makes ChatGPT has told US Congress that government intervention will be critical to mitigating the risks of increasingly powerful AI systems. "As this technology advances, we understand that people are anxious about how it could change the way we live. We are too," OpenAI CEO Sam Altman told a Senate hearing. Altman proposed the formation of a US or global agency that would license the most powerful AI systems and have the authority to "take that license away and ensure compliance with safety standards." His San Francisco-based company rocketed to public attention after it released its AI chatbot ChatGPT last year. Senator Richard Blumenthal had opened the hearing with a recorded speech that sounded like his voice, but was actually a voice clone trained on his speeches and reciting a speech written by ChatGPT. The result was impressive, Blumenthal said, but he added: "What if I had asked it, and what if it had provided, an endorsement of Ukraine surrendering or [Russian President] Vladimir Putin's leadership?"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The boss of OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT, tells US Congress regulation is needed

props.alt: A white man in a suit sits at a bench in US Congress, with people behind him, and speaks into a microphone. Water and his name tage on the desk in front of him

children.content: (AP: Patrick Semansky)
The head of the artificial intelligence company that makes ChatGPT has told US Congress that government intervention will be critical to mitigating the risks of increasingly powerful AI systems.
"As this technology advances, we understand that people are anxious about how it could change the way we live. We are too," OpenAI CEO Sam Altman told a Senate hearing.
Altman proposed the formation of a US or global agency that would license the most powerful AI systems
and have the authority to "take that license away and ensure compliance with safety standards."
His San Francisco-based company rocketed to public attention after it released its AI chatbot ChatGPT last year.
Senator Richard Blumenthal had opened the hearing with a recorded speech that sounded like his voice, but
was actually a voice clone
trained on his speeches and reciting a speech written by ChatGPT.
The result was impressive, Blumenthal said, but he added:
"What if I had asked it, and what if it had provided, an endorsement of Ukraine surrendering or [Russian President] Vladimir Putin's leadership?"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In case you missed it yesterday — Australians are still searching for information about the deadly fire which took place in a hostel in the New Zealand capital, Wellington. The blaze on Tuesday morning has killed at least six people, while 11 remain missing. The building also sustained extensive damage, and police say their investigations can't get fully underway until a safety assessment is carried out — which is expected to happen today. An Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade spokesperson says they have confirmed that police have not identified any Australian citizens who have been impacted. You can keep reading more about what happened, here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: News Australia is searching for: Wellington hostel fire

featuredLink.title: What we know about the Loafers Lodge hostel fire

props.alt: An exterior of a hostel building, with a firetruck out the front

children.content: (AP: Nick James/NZ Herald)
In case you missed it yesterday — Australians are still searching for information about the deadly fire which took place in a hostel in the New Zealand capital, Wellington.
The blaze on Tuesday morning
has killed at least six people, while 11 remain missing
The building also sustained extensive damage, and police say their investigations can't get fully underway until a safety assessment is carried out — which is expected to happen today.
An Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade spokesperson says they have confirmed that police have not identified any Australian citizens who have been impacted.
You can keep reading more about what happened, here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Grammy-nominated English rapper Slowthai has appeared in court after being accused of raping a woman — a crime he denies carrying out. As the BBC reports, the 28-year-old singer has been charged under his real name, Tyron Kaymone Frampton. He appeared before court on Tuesday via video link from his home. Frampton has been charged with two counts of raping a woman in September 2021. In a statement on social media, Frampton says he denies the charges. "I am innocent and I am confident my name will be cleared," he says, before asking fans not to comment about the situation. Frampton is expected to appear before Oxford Crown Court on 15 June. His latest Slowthai album Ugly came out in March this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: English rapper Slowthai issues denial after being charged with rape

props.alt: A man holding an award and a beer, smiles next to a Mercury Prize press backdrop

children.content: (Reuters: Henry Nicholls)
Grammy-nominated English rapper Slowthai has appeared in court after being accused of raping a woman — a crime he denies carrying out.
As the BBC reports, the 28-year-old singer has been charged under his real name,
Tyron Kaymone Frampton
He appeared before court on Tuesday via video link from his home.
Frampton has been
charged with two counts of raping a woman in September 2021
In a statement on social media, Frampton says
he denies the charges
"I am innocent and I am confident my name will be cleared," he says, before asking fans not to comment about the situation.
Frampton is expected to appear before Oxford Crown Court on 15 June.
His latest Slowthai album Ugly came out in March this year.

image.altText: A man with grey hair with a fireman's hat behind him

items.synopsis: Despite being gradually phased out, the toxic chemicals are still found in products like household cookware, waterproof jackets, stain resistant carpets and food packaging, experts say.

title.children: 'It's in everyone's blood': Australian government urged to ban PFAS chemicals amid health concerns

image.altText: Anita Nedoskyko is underwater looking at a big crab, a sign the man made native shellfish reef is successful.

items.synopsis: Early settlers who fished native reefs with rakes and chains left them devoid of marine life but a project in Tasmania is the latest example of how the tide is being turned many years later.

title.children: 'Critters starting to grow': Rebuilt reefs teeming with marine life

image.altText: People move from their homes to take shelter in the nearest cyclone shelter.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people, including Rohingya Muslims, are feared dead after a cyclone rocks Myanmar, as rescue efforts are hampered by damage to infrastructure.

title.children: Hundreds feared dead, including Rohingya Muslims, after cyclone Mocha

image.altText: A wooden carving depicting a woman

items.synopsis: Art Gallery of New South Wales has returned an 800-year-old wooden carving to the Nepalese temple it was taken from, but after 20 years of work, and with so many more stolen pieces in their collection, experts say more needs to be done.

title.children: Sydney gallery returns stolen Nepalese carving, despite knowing for 20 years it was stolen

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff with a football.

items.synopsis: As the game involving the political football — aka Hobart's AFL stadium — enters what could be the final quarter, Tasmania may find itself facing a constitutional crisis, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: Jeremy Rockliff is one vote away from losing power. But how likely is that to happen?

image.altText: Close up of a Tasmania Police cap.

items.synopsis: Australia is experiencing a shortage of police officers, with some states embarking on overseas recruitment drives and one state trying to sign people up at football games.

title.children: Police recruitment crisis putting officers and community 'at risk'

image.altText: A yellow Ray White sign that says "lease" in front of a freestanding home.

items.synopsis: There are at least four things that would do more to restrain rents than Labor’s $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund – and one of them would do it a lot quicker, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Four ways to bring down rent and build homes faster than Labor's $10 billion housing fund

image.altText: The top of the structure under water.

items.synopsis: Greenpeace has released underwater footage of Woodside's sunken riser turret mooring off the West Australian coast. The activist group says the structure is "decaying" and poses a contamination risk.

title.children: 'Decaying' gas tower structure needs to be removed from WA ocean floor, Greenpeace says

image.altText: Keys rang from lock, in a front door.

items.synopsis: The chief executive of the Real Estate Institute of Australia says a solution to the rental crisis is to make better use of existing houses and to build more.

title.children: Councils called to push landlords to make vacant or holiday homes available for renters

image.altText: RBA building

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) warns further interest rate increases are still possible, as a former RBA governor says the low-rate era is over, leaving households feeling like Australia is heading for recession.

title.children: House price rebound appears to have clinched RBA rate rise in May, minutes reveal

image.altText: Katy, a middle-aged woman in a salmon-pink top, sits at a table looking serious

items.synopsis: Home owner Katy says she's been struggling to meet her loan demands, and fears losing her home. What are the steps between missing a payment and losing your property?

title.children: Australians sell investment properties, refinance mortgages 'at a rate never before seen'

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit.

items.synopsis: A transcript of closed proceedings during the trial of Bruce Lehrmann, which has been released to an ACT board of inquiry, reveals the jury never discussed the research paper that saw the case abandoned.

title.children: Prohibited research that caused Lehrmann trial to be abandoned was never discussed by jury, transcript reveals

image.altText: A white bus on its side surrounded by emergency services personnel in high vis.

items.synopsis: Victoria Police says 45 children were on their way home on the school bus when it was struck by a truck and rolled at Eynesbury just before 4pm.

title.children: Truck and school bus collide west of Melbourne, leaving 10 children seriously injured

image.altText: A close-up shot of the District Court of WA in Perth, showing signage on the building's front facade with the court's name.

items.synopsis: A WA man will spend at least three decades behind bars for breaking into three houses and sexually assaulting the female occupants during a rampage in Kalgoorlie-Boulder. WARNING: This article contains details that readers may find distressing.

title.children: 'Every woman's worst nightmare': Man jailed for 32 years after sexually assaulting three women

image.altText: Victoria, who has shoulder-length blonde hair, looks calmly at the camera in a close-up portrait.

items.synopsis: On the day former police officer Brett Johnson is sentenced for abusing his position of power to pursue vulnerable women, one of his victims speaks exclusively to the ABC about the devastating impact his offending had on her life.

title.children: A police officer's misconduct shattered Victoria's life. He has now been jailed for six months

image.altText: Photo shows a part of the collection at White Silver Room inside Dresden's Green Vault where gold valuables hang

items.synopsis: A German court convicts five men over the theft of 18th-century jewels worth more than 100 million euros ($163 million) from a Dresden museum.

title.children: Five Germans sentenced for $163 million jewellery heist

image.altText: A missile is shot down over Kyiv, leaving a ball of light and a vertical trial of smoke in dark night sky.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it shot down all 18 missiles launched by Russia in what Kyiv authorities describe as an "exceptional" attack, while China's top diplomat is due to tour Ukraine and Russia aiming to discuss a "political settlement" to the war.

title.children: Russia launches cruise and ballistic missiles in one of its most intense attacks on Ukraine

image.altText: A young woman with shoulder-length dark hair looking straight ahead.

items.synopsis: Robert and Anne Geeves, who were living with 19-year-old Amber Haigh at the time of her disappearance in June 2002, have been committed to stand trial on murder charges.

title.children: Married couple accused of murdering teenage mother in 2002 plead not guilty

image.altText: Stills of video which played a role in the Australian's four month investigation

items.synopsis: The South Australian government will spearhead a national review into the origins of First Nations artwork following allegations non-Indigenous workers have interfered in works by Aboriginal artists.

title.children: South Australian government to probe 'serious allegations' of interference in Aboriginal art

image.altText: A person in all white protective gear treating a big area of black mould on the wall of a house

items.synopsis: Rental properties are more likely be mouldy than other homes and excessive mould growth is known to harm human health. So what can you do about it?

title.children: We're heading in to 'mega mould' season and renters are at greater risk

image.altText: A firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning through a structure.

items.synopsis: A Rural Fire Service commander tells an inquest into the 2019-20 bushfire disaster that he did not ignore concerns raised by a pilot about the decision to conduct a back-burn that jumped containment lines when the weather changed.

title.children: RFS commander defends decision to start Black Summer back-burn that led to destruction of 100 homes

image.altText: A digital illustration of a lumpy comet body emitting gas in a halo around it.

items.synopsis: The discovery of water vapour around a "main belt comet" inside Jupiter's orbit is being hailed as a breakthrough in understanding where Earth's abundant water came from.

title.children: Confirmation of water ice in asteroid belt may help solve mystery of Earth's oceans

image.altText: Homelessness epidemic

items.synopsis: An Australian Army veteran, who alleges she was sexually assaulted twice while serving, blasts the response from the Department of Defence at the time.

title.children: 'I was blamed': Former soldier says she was sexually assaulted twice but Defence offered little support

image.altText: A dog sits in a sling as people in red coats gather around it.

items.synopsis: A dog is rescued after hiking up Scafell Pike and becoming too exhausted to walk back down.

title.children: Dog rescued from England's tallest mountain after injuring itself
